study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psilocybin-assisted therapy (PAT) could attenuate personality abnormalities in patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and whether reductions in trait impulsiveness were associated with lower alcohol consumption.
results_summary: The psilocybin group showed significant reductions in neuroticism and increases in extraversion and openness compared to placebo, with decreases in impulsiveness linked to lower posttreatment alcohol consumption, particularly among those with prior moderate- or high-risk drinking.
population_specificity: Adults with alcohol use disorder (AUD) (N=84).
effective_dosage: Two medication sessions (psilocybin or diphenhydramine), exact dosage not specified.
study_duration: 12 weeks of psychotherapy plus 24 weeks of follow-up (total 36 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of psilocybin in patients with severely treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: Psilocybin significantly reduced depressive symptoms at 3 and 12 weeks post-treatment, with the Oceanic Boundlessness dimension correlating with antidepressant responses. Patients with comorbid PTSD showed less antidepressant effect.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with severe TRD (insufficient benefit from at least five prior treatments).
interactions: Psychotropic medications were discontinued 2 weeks prior to dosing through 3 weeks post-dosing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence base for psilocybin with psychological support/therapy (PST) in treating psychiatric disorders and provide recommendations for future research.
results_summary: The study found the most developed evidence for psilocybin in treating major depressive disorder (MDD), with positive signals in three double-blind RCTs, but noted limitations like small samples, unsuccessful blinding, and variability in dosing. Overall, the evidence was deemed insufficient to recommend psilocybin with PST as a psychiatric treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with obsessive-compulsive and related disorders, anxiety/depression linked to cancer, MDD, substance use disorders, anorexia, and demoralization in AIDS survivors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neurobiological mechanisms underlying the therapeutic effects of psilocybin-assisted psychotherapy (PAP) in treating eating disorders (EDs).
results_summary: The study suggests emerging evidence for the safety and efficacy of PAP in improving treatment outcomes for EDs but highlights limited knowledge of its neurobiological mechanisms. It reviews methodologies like MRI and molecular neuroimaging to probe these mechanisms.
population_specificity: Individuals with eating disorders (EDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a structured psychological support framework (CPSM) to enhance the safety and meaningfulness of psilocybin experiences in clinical trials for treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: The study introduced the Compass Psychological Support Model (CPSM) to provide psychological support during psilocybin treatment, emphasizing therapist training and fidelity assessment to ensure consistent delivery. The framework aims to optimize the therapeutic potential of psilocybin for mental health conditions.
population_specificity: Individuals with treatment-resistant depression participating in Compass-sponsored clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and safety of psilocybin-assisted psychotherapy (PAT) for treating methamphetamine (MA) dependence.
results_summary: The study found that PAT following inpatient withdrawal management led to significant cognitive and emotional shifts, sustained MA abstinence, and improved mental health, self-esteem, mindfulness, and distress tolerance in a daily MA user.
population_specificity: A 36-year-old transwoman and daily MA user.
study_duration: One session of psilocybin-assisted therapy, with follow-up over 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate psilocybin's potential as a disease-modifying therapy for ALS, focusing on its mechanisms and safety.
results_summary: The study found no pre-clinical ALS models, case reports, or trials supporting psilocybin's efficacy in slowing ALS progression, and highlighted risks of psychological side effects like hallucinations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general ALS context).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dosing mentioned as variable but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of sex and peri-acute negative experiences (stress) in the acute and post-acute mood-altering effects of psilocybin.
results_summary: Psilocybin increased head-twitch response frequency more in female mice than males. It induced anxiolytic-like effects, which were fully blocked by stress in males but only partially in females. Stress and psilocybin independently increased corticosterone levels without additive effects.
population_specificity: Adult male and female C57BL/6J mice
study_duration: Acute administration with behavioral assessments starting 24 hours post-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the enduring effects of psilocybin-assisted therapy on empathy in depressed patients using a randomized, placebo-controlled design.
results_summary: Patients who received psilocybin showed significant improvements in explicit emotional empathy, particularly towards positive stimuli, compared to the placebo group for at least two weeks. The study suggests psilocybin may enhance social cognition in individuals with depression.
population_specificity: Fifty-one depressed patients.
study_duration: 4-week psychological support intervention with follow-up measurements at 2 days, 1 week, and 2 weeks post-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collate and evaluate adverse event data from psilocybin-assisted psychotherapy clinical trials, focusing on definition, measurement, and reporting methods.
results_summary: The review found that psilocybin-assisted psychotherapy was generally safe, with common adverse events including elevated blood pressure, headaches, nausea, and anxiety. Suicidal ideation and behavior were rare and mainly observed in participants with a history of such tendencies.
population_specificity: Clinical populations, particularly those with treatment-resistant depression.
effective_dosage: Heterogeneous doses (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight potential adverse events of psilocybin and underline the limitations of quantitative methodology in clinical trials for treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin could temporarily worsen suicidal ideation and cause prolonged adverse events, yet paradoxically, participants reported functional improvements not captured by rating scales. The case demonstrated mixed outcomes, with both destabilization and perceived personal benefits.
population_specificity: A participant in a phase 2b clinical trial for treatment-resistant depression.

study_goal: To determine the relationships between psilocybin dose, psychedelic experiences, and therapeutic outcome in treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: The intensity of psychedelic effects was dose-related, with depression response correlating with specific aspects of the psychedelic experience. At the 25 mg dose, certain dimensions of the psychedelic experience showed the strongest correlation to improved depression scores at Week 3.
population_specificity: 233 participants with treatment-resistant depression
effective_dosage: Single doses of 25, 10, or 1 mg of COMP360 psilocybin
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up at 3 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antidepressant effects of psilocybin-assisted therapy (PAT) versus comparator treatments in major depressive disorder (MDD), including treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: Psilocybin-assisted therapy showed superior antidepressant effects compared to control interventions, with medium to large effect sizes sustained for up to 6 weeks. Adverse effects, though increased, were generally mild (e.g., headache, dizziness).
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD), including treatment-resistant depression.
study_duration: Effects were assessed up to 6 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of psilocybin as an anti-nociceptive agent in preclinical animal models and its translational potential for chronic pain patients.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin shows promise in reducing chronic pain through serotonergic pathways and neuroplastic actions, improving functional connectivity in brain regions involved in pain, but further research is needed.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal models (neuropathic and inflammatory pain) and potential chronic pain patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and long-term effects of psilocybin in treating mental disorders, focusing on depression, substance use disorders, and anxiety.
results_summary: Psilocybin demonstrated strong efficacy against depression (including treatment-resistant cases) with effect sizes (Cohen's d) ranging from 0.67 to 2.6. It also showed promise for alcohol use disorders and anxiety in life-threatening illnesses like cancer.
population_specificity: Patients with depression, substance use disorders (particularly alcohol), and anxiety related to life-threatening somatic illnesses (e.g., cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psilocybin therapy could improve symptoms of depression, burnout, and PTSD in clinicians who developed these conditions from frontline work during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Psilocybin therapy resulted in a significant reduction in depression symptoms compared to niacin, with a mean difference of -12.00 on the MADRS scale. While improvements in burnout and PTSD symptoms were numerically larger in the psilocybin group, these changes did not reach statistical significance.
population_specificity: Physicians, advanced practice practitioners (APPs), and nurses who provided frontline care during the pandemic and had moderate or severe depression symptoms but no prepandemic mental health diagnoses.
effective_dosage: 25 mg psilocybin orally in a single medication session.
study_duration: The intervention included 2 preparation visits, 1 medication session, and 3 integration visits, with outcomes measured at day 28 post-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore psilocybin's potential as a therapeutic agent for mental health, including its use in clinical trials for severe psychiatric conditions and low-dose applications for general well-being.
results_summary: The study highlights psilocybin's versatility in treating depression and anxiety through personalized dosing and its integration into wellness products, suggesting it could reshape mental health treatment paradigms.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract mentions various contexts but no specific population).
effective_dosage: Not specified (mentions personalized dosing and low-dose applications but no exact amounts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the legal and ethical considerations surrounding psilocybin as a potential treatment for psychiatric illnesses.
results_summary: The abstract highlights psilocybin's promising potential for treating psychiatric conditions but notes unresolved legal and ethical issues, including regulation, access, and provider-patient dynamics.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of psychiatric illnesses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate psilocybin's chemical properties, mechanisms of action, and therapeutic potential in psychiatric treatment, while proposing future research directions.
results_summary: The study highlights psilocybin's high therapeutic potential in psychiatry, supported by clinical evidence, and notes its safety in trials with manageable side effects, though additional safety measures are recommended.
population_specificity: Not specified (general psychiatric applications discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and therapeutic efficacy of psilocybin-assisted therapy (PAT) for depression and anxiety, particularly in patients with life-threatening diseases.
results_summary: PAT showed significant immediate and partially sustained improvements in depressive and anxious symptomatology, with comparable efficacy to selective serotonergic reuptake inhibitors in one study. The therapy was found safe and feasible in clinical models, though larger, more diverse studies are needed for stronger conclusions.
population_specificity: General population with depressive symptoms and patients with somatic life-threatening diseases experiencing depression and anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess patient attitudes toward participating in a trial examining psilocybin for chronic neuropathic pain and identify factors influencing willingness to participate.
results_summary: Most participants (76.9%) were willing to join the trial, with prior psychedelic use being higher among "willing" participants. Motivations included the need for new treatments and personal pain management benefits, while discouraging factors were practical difficulties and potential adverse events.
population_specificity: 26 patients with chronic neuropathic pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of psilocybin on sleep quality and its relationship with depressive symptom improvements.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin significantly reduced both depressive symptoms and sleep disturbances, though sleep improvements were smaller. Baseline sleep disturbances were linked to lower depression remission rates, suggesting a potential interaction between sleep and psilocybin's efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess psychiatrists' knowledge and attitudes toward psilocybin therapy in Ireland to understand its potential impact on clinical practice and public health.
results_summary: Most psychiatrists (81.5%) agreed psilocybin therapy shows promise for psychiatric disorders, with 86.8% supporting research funding and willingness to refer patients if licensed. However, 21.9% thought it potentially addictive, and only 9.9% felt prepared to participate in therapy.
population_specificity: Psychiatrists in Ireland (151 participants, 73.3% under 40, 76.0% trainees, 49.0% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sustainable production process for psilocybin using engineered fungal strains to meet future therapeutic demands.
results_summary: The study demonstrated a fivefold increase in psilocybin production in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and a 10-fold increase in Aspergillus nidulans through genetic modifications and process optimization, achieving a final titre of 267 mg/L.
population_specificity: Engineered fungal strains (Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Aspergillus nidulans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psilocybin in treating depression compared to established psychotherapy alone.
results_summary: The study found a large and clinically significant reduction in depressive symptoms with psilocybin compared to baseline and placebo, with sustained effects over time.
population_specificity: Patients with depression

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of acute psilocybin administration on compulsive-like behaviors in SAPAP3 knockout mice, a model for obsessive-compulsive and related disorders.
results_summary: Acute psilocybin administration led to enduring reductions in compulsive behavior in male SAPAP3 KO mice and reduced grooming behavior in female WT and SAPAP3 KO mice, with effects lasting up to 1 week post-injection. Psilocybin increased locomotion in WT mice but not in KO mice, while the hallucinogenic-like head-twitch response was observed in both genotypes.
population_specificity: Male and female SAPAP3 knockout (KO) mice and wild-type (WT) littermates.
study_duration: Effects assessed at 1, 3, and 8 days post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the structure and function of PsiK, an enzyme involved in psilocybin biosynthesis, to support future bioengineering efforts for enhanced therapeutic properties.
results_summary: The study provided crystallographic and mutagenesis insights into PsiK's substrate recognition, which will aid in bioengineering psilocybin variants with improved therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risks of psilocybin use in individuals with predisposing factors for psychosis, based on a case report and review of similar cases.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin can induce psychotic episodes, particularly in individuals with predisposing risk factors (e.g., depression, personality disorder traits, cannabis use) who consume high or repeated doses. This reinforces concerns about psilocybin's safety in vulnerable populations.
population_specificity: Individuals with predisposing risk factors for psychosis (e.g., history of depression, personality disorder traits, cannabis use).
effective_dosage: Heavy psilocybin use (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether discontinuation of antidepressant drugs affects the efficacy and subjective psychedelic experience of psilocybin treatment in individuals with treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: The study found that antidepressant discontinuation did not worsen depression severity before baseline, and psilocybin treatment efficacy and subjective psychedelic effects were not compromised by prior antidepressant use. The results support psilocybin as a feasible monotherapy for treatment-resistant depression.
population_specificity: 233 participants with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
effective_dosage: 25 mg, 10 mg, or 1 mg of COMP360 psilocybin (single administration).
study_duration: Primary endpoint measured at Week 3 post-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss psilocybin's impact on glutamatergic neurotransmission and its therapeutic potential for depression and other nervous system disorders.
results_summary: Psilocybin acts as a 5-HT2A receptor agonist, increasing glutamate release in the frontal cortex and hippocampus, which enhances GABAergic interneuron activity and may promote antidepressant effects. It also appears to influence neuroplasticity via the glutamatergic pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (clinical and preclinical studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of psilocybin-assisted frontal-midline theta neurofeedback for improving executive functions.
results_summary: The study found no task-based improvements in executive functions but reported significant self-reported gains in daily executive functions (working memory, shifting, monitoring, and inhibition) with medium to high effect sizes. The experimental group also showed significant gains in their key training goals, indicating external relevance.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven eligible participants with executive function deficits, randomized into an experimental group (n = 18) and a passive control group (n = 19).
effective_dosage: Three microdose sessions followed by three psilocybin-assisted neurofeedback sessions (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but involved six sessions (three microdose and three neurofeedback).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify concerns and facilitating factors regarding the acceptability and access to psilocybin-assisted therapy among palliative care professionals.
results_summary: Palliative care professionals expressed interest in psilocybin-assisted therapy but highlighted concerns such as training needs, legalization, research gaps, and protocol refinement. Acceptability and access expansion were found to be interrelated.
population_specificity: 16 palliative care professionals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of psilocybin in cellular and animal models of stroke.
results_summary: Psilocybin reduced glutamate-mediated neuronal loss in rat cortical cultures and reduced brain infarction and neurological deficits in stroke rats. It also improved locomotor behavior and regulated BDNF expression, with these effects being attenuated by the BDNF inhibitor ANA12.
population_specificity: Adult male and timed-pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of psilocybin in reducing excessive self-grooming and anxiety behaviors in SAPAP3 KO mice, a model for OCD-like symptoms.
results_summary: Psilocybin and psychedelic mushroom extract significantly reduced self-grooming behaviors, head-body twitches, and anxiety in SAPAP3 KO mice, with effects persisting up to 7 weeks in responders. The mushroom extract showed superior effects on secondary outcomes compared to pure psilocybin.
population_specificity: SAPAP3 KO mice (28 male, 22 female) exhibiting OCD-like behaviors.
study_duration: 21-day observation period, with some effects tracked up to 7 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, safety, and tolerability of psilocybin in treating major depressive disorder (MDD) in adults through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Psilocybin showed beneficial effects on depressive symptoms in 60% of the included studies and significantly improved anxiety symptoms in 80% of the studies assessing this outcome. Discontinuation rates and adverse drug reactions were similar between psilocybin and control groups, with headache being the most common adverse reaction.
population_specificity: Physically healthy adult patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore psilocybin as a potential treatment option for PTSD by examining its neurobiological mechanisms and pharmacodynamic principles.
results_summary: The abstract suggests psilocybin may be an underexplored treatment for PTSD, but further research is required to confirm its efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of subjective effects and dissociation in mediating psilocybin-induced therapeutic outcomes for depression and substance use disorder (SUD).
results_summary: The study found a greater mediating effect of subjective symptoms for psilocybin compared to ketamine, particularly in depression, with an R2-value of 24%. Psilocybin showed stronger therapeutic mediation in SUD than in depression.
population_specificity: Patients with depression or substance use disorder (SUD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate psilocybin's potential neuroprotective and neuroplastic effects as a prophylactic therapeutic against Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: Psilocybin may promote neuron repair via 5-HT2A receptor activation, increasing BDNF release and reducing α-synuclein accumulation, suggesting potential benefits for PD prevention.
population_specificity: Cell and animal models (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the information processing mechanisms affected by psilocybin, particularly its effects on belief updating and optimism bias in a behavioral task.
results_summary: Psilocybin increased task engagement and reward achievement in rats by modifying forgetting rates and reducing loss aversion, suggesting an optimism bias through altered belief updating.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate psilocybin's effects on cognitive function and its potential benefits and risks in psychiatric disorders.
results_summary: Psilocybin showed mixed effects on cognitive function, with no significant changes in global cognition or processing speed in healthy individuals but improvements in sustained attention, working memory, and executive function in treatment-resistant depression (TRD) patients. Emotional processing and empathy were positively modified, while cognitive flexibility and creative cognition initially declined but potentially improved over time.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (85% of studies) and patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
effective_dosage: Macrodoses ranging from 45 μg/kg to 30 mg/70 kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of psilocybin in Veterans with severe treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: At 3 weeks posttreatment, 60% of participants met response criteria and 53% met remission criteria; at 12 weeks, 47% maintained response and 40% remission. No unexpected adverse events occurred, and the psychedelic experience did not correlate with depression changes.
population_specificity: Veterans with severe treatment-resistant depression (TRD), some with comorbid PTSD.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 3 and 12 weeks posttreatment.
interactions: Participants on antidepressants were tapered to avoid drug interactions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore novel lysergic acid derivatives and innovative dosing methods for psilocybin, as well as its potential in treating binge eating disorder and enhancing emotional responses.
results_summary: The study highlights advancements in psychedelic research, including modified LSD-like actions and personalized dosing strategies based on ABCF1 gene expression, suggesting therapeutic potential for mental health treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, tolerability, and effects of low-dose oral psilocybin with psychological support on headache severity, frequency, and cognition in patients with chronic SUNHA.
results_summary: No significant adverse events were recorded, but cognitive function could not be assessed due to high subjective dose intensity. Limited effects on headache duration and severity were observed, though two participants showed a >50% reduction in daily attack frequency.
population_specificity: Four patients with chronic SUNHA (three completers).
effective_dosage: Ascending doses of 5, 7.5, and 10 mg (one dose per session; three dosing sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate psilocybin's potential as a treatment for Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) in a patient with refractory symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin provided significant pain relief and functional improvement in the patient, suggesting its potential efficacy for chronic pain management.
population_specificity: A single patient with refractory CRPS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of psilocybin-assisted therapy (PAT) for alleviating existential distress in a patient with stage 4 astrocytoma.
results_summary: The patient responded positively to PAT without adverse events, and the therapy partially alleviated existential distress. The study highlights the need for expanded access to PAT, especially for patients with brain cancer.
population_specificity: A single patient with end-of-life distress secondary to stage 4 astrocytoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and identify knowledge gaps concerning the pharmacokinetic characteristics of psilocybin and its active metabolite, psilocin.
results_summary: Psilocybin is rapidly converted to psilocin, which reaches peak plasma and brain levels dose-dependently, with a half-life of 2-3 hours. The review identified gaps in pharmacokinetic data and study limitations that could guide future research.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between different psychological protocols and the efficacy of psilocybin-assisted therapy for depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin-assisted therapy significantly improved depressive symptoms, with a pooled standard mean difference of 10.08, but the improvement was not associated with the type of psychological protocol used.
population_specificity: 515 adult patients with clinically diagnosed depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of single-dose and two-dose psilocybin administration on depressive symptom severity in patients with MDD or TRD.
results_summary: Psilocybin significantly reduced depressive symptoms in patients with MDD or TRD, with two-dose administration sometimes producing more pronounced and lasting effects, though the exact reason for this difference remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with a primary diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) or treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
effective_dosage: Single-dose and two-dose psilocybin treatments (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psilocybin enhances extinction following cocaine self-administration and attenuates cue-induced drug-seeking in mice and rats.
results_summary: Psilocybin had no effect on cocaine-seeking behavior in both male and female mice and rats, as significant cue-induced reinstatement was observed regardless of treatment. The study suggests psilocybin is ineffective under the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Male and female mice (16 female, 19 male) and rats (24 female, 23 male).
effective_dosage: Mice: 1.0 mg/kg psilocybin; Rats: 1.0 mg/kg or 2.5 mg/kg psilocybin.
study_duration: Mice: 8 days of cocaine self-administration and extinction training; Rats: 15 days of cocaine self-administration and extinction training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether psilocybin-producing species of Inocybaceae are monophyletic and to explore the evolutionary history of muscarine and psilocybin in these fungi.
results_summary: The study found that psilocybin production evolved independently in at least two lineages of Inocybaceae, with transitions occurring after muscarine loss. Muscarine was not ancestral for the family but represents a conserved trait in some clades.
population_specificity: Inocybaceae fungi, primarily from tropical and southern hemisphere temperate regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether the resurgence of psychedelics in mental health treatment represents a true paradigm shift or an integration into existing therapeutic frameworks.
results_summary: The study found that while psychedelics offer rapid therapeutic effects and unique mechanisms, they should be viewed as enhancements to existing psychiatric models rather than a complete paradigm shift, cautioning against overestimating their revolutionary potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of psychedelic therapy in psychiatry)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess psychedelic practitioners' viewpoints on psychological support strategies for psychedelic treatments, comparing emotive and neuromodulatory approaches.
results_summary: The study found no consensus on psychological support strategies but identified an aggregate preference for an emotive approach, particularly among practitioners trained at MAPS or CIIS. Four latent factors were identified, including trust, spirituality, emotional setting, and conceptualizing negative experiences.
population_specificity: Psychedelic practitioners in research settings (42.5% MD/DO, 57.5% other) from at least 4 countries, 11 U.S. states, and 16 institutions.
study_duration: Data collected from March 2023 to July 2023 (intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the historical development, therapeutic applications, and potential treatment effects of psychedelic therapy, particularly in depression, trauma disorders, and substance use disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights that psychedelics, especially psilocybin, show promising potential in treating neuropsychiatric diseases like treatment-resistant depression and substance addictions, with significant effects reported in psychotherapy-assisted applications for cancer-related anxiety and depression.
population_specificity: Patients with life-threatening cancer-related anxiety and depression, treatment-resistant depression, and substance use disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the subjective effects of LSD and psilocybin between patients undergoing psychedelic-assisted therapy (PAT) and healthy volunteers, and to investigate the relationship between antidepressant effects and acute drug effects in patients.
results_summary: Ratings of overall drug effect and mystical experience were similar across groups, but patients reported lower ego dissolution. PAT significantly reduced depressive symptoms, with relaxation during sessions being the strongest predictor of antidepressant outcomes, while mystical experiences showed no relationship with efficacy. Most adverse effects were mild and resolved within 48 hours.
population_specificity: 28 PAT patients with depressive symptoms and 28 healthy volunteers.
effective_dosage: Varying doses of psilocybin and LSD (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate existing approaches to integrating psychotherapy with psychedelic administration and provide recommendations for optimizing therapeutic benefits.
results_summary: The systematic review highlights the lack of consensus on integrating psychedelic experiences with evidence-based psychotherapy and offers clear recommendations for improving therapeutic outcomes and scientific inference.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad focus on psychiatric disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sage oil in mitigating obesity-induced testicular apoptosis, oxidative stress, and reduced spermatogenesis in male rats.
results_summary: Sage oil supplementation normalized body weight, reduced testicular oxidative stress and apoptosis, and improved sperm count and germ cell proliferation in obese rats.
population_specificity: Dietary-induced obese male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of patient satisfaction in outpatient health services in China using data from the WHO SAGE survey.
results_summary: The study found that self-reported treatment outcomes and patient-rated communication were the strongest predictors of satisfaction, with logistic regression and random forests predicting satisfaction with 74% accuracy. Dissatisfaction was rare (1.8%).
population_specificity: Adult populations in China, particularly those utilizing outpatient health services.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether anticoagulation satisfaction differs among atrial fibrillation (AF) patients with and without physical, cognitive, and psychosocial conditions.
results_summary: The study found that visual impairment, depressive symptoms, and anxiety were significantly associated with high perceived anticoagulation burden. Different conditions were linked to high burden in warfarin versus direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) users.
population_specificity: AF patients aged 65 years or older prescribed oral anticoagulants (warfarin or DOACs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of SAGE-217, an oral GABA type A receptor modulator, in treating major depressive disorder.
results_summary: SAGE-217 significantly reduced depressive symptoms compared to placebo at day 15, with a mean HAM-D score reduction of -17.4 vs. -10.3. Adverse events like headache and dizziness were more common in the SAGE-217 group, but no serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid method for quantifying terpenes and terpenoids in Sage essential oil and assess their variation in commercial samples and degradation under ozone treatment.
results_summary: The study found significant variation in terpene and terpenoid content among commercial Sage oils, with some samples dominated by toxic thujones and others containing none. Ozone treatment degraded sabinene and β-pinene but left α/β-thujone more resistant.
population_specificity: Commercial Sage essential oils and fresh Sage leaves.

study_goal: The researchers sought to assess geriatric impairments in patients with atrial fibrillation and determine if these impairments influenced oral anticoagulant prescribing.
results_summary: Geriatric impairments (e.g., cognitive impairment, frailty) were common in the cohort, but oral anticoagulant prescribing did not vary by impairment status, suggesting prescribers may overlook these factors.
population_specificity: Patients aged 65+ with atrial fibrillation, CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2, and no contraindications to oral anticoagulants (n = 1244).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the physiological responses and stress acclimatization of two sage cultivars ('Icterina' and 'Purpurascens') under chilling conditions (4 °C) versus control (18 °C).
results_summary: Chilling induced dynamic changes in enzyme activity (APX, GPX) and antioxidant capacity in 'Purpurascens,' while 'Icterina' showed more stable responses. 'Purpurascens' exhibited increased phenolic content and antioxidant capacity under stress, whereas chilling reduced dry matter content in both cultivars.
population_specificity: Two sage cultivars ('Icterina' and 'Purpurascens')

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the survival status of older adults (50+ years) who were HIV-negative, HIV-positive not on ART, and HIV-positive on ART in Uganda.
results_summary: The study found that older adults living with HIV on ART had nearly twice the mortality risk compared to HIV-negative adults, while those not on ART had the highest risk. The adjusted hazard ratio for mortality was 1.75 (ART group) and 2.09 (non-ART group) compared to HIV-negative participants.
population_specificity: Older adults (50+ years) in rural and peri-urban Uganda, including HIV-negative and HIV-positive individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sage extract, both alone and in combination with enterocin M, on rabbit growth, feed conversion, microbial activity, and fermentation.
results_summary: Sage extract reduced propionic and butyric acid levels while increasing concentrations of other fatty acids and lactic acid. It also showed a prolonged reduction effect on amylolytic activity and improved enzymatic activities in the caecum.
population_specificity: Rabbits (weaned and older animals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of the SAGE intervention in promoting physical activity and fruit and vegetable consumption among young children in early care and education centers.
results_summary: The study designed a garden-based curriculum to engage children in healthy lifestyle activities, but specific efficacy results are not detailed in the abstract. The intervention included active learning, dietary observation, and parent engagement components.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-5 years in early care and education centers (20 sites).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physicochemical and functional properties of poly(ε-caprolactone) films containing sage extract for potential use in active food packaging to prevent oxidation and microbial growth.
results_summary: The study found that sage extract incorporation into PCL films provided strong antioxidant and antimicrobial activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli, while minimally affecting tensile properties and thermal stability. Water vapor and aroma permeability increased with sage extract addition.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on film properties)
effective_dosage: 5%, 10%, and 20% loading contents of sage extract in PCL films

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the SAGE hybrid model in improving knee image segmentation by reducing interobserver error and user intervention.
results_summary: SAGE achieved high interobserver Dice Similarity Coefficients (DSCs) in both healthy and osteoarthritic (OA) knee segmentation, with consistent performance across femoral, tibial, and patellar cartilage. It also demonstrated improved efficiency with reduced user input time.
population_specificity: Knee images from healthy individuals and those with osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate predictors of hypertension prevalence and management in South Africa, including traditional risk factors and sociodemographic indicators.
results_summary: The study found that 43% of adults were hypertensive, with low awareness (58% unaware) and control (18% controlled on medication). Waist-to-height ratio > 0.5 and diabetes comorbidity were significant predictors of hypertension presence, awareness, and treatment.
population_specificity: Adults in South Africa (n=1847; 68% female; median age 51 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-inflammatory effect of the flavonoid fraction of Lepechinia meyenii (Sage) on leukocytes from patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The flavonoid fraction LM8 reduced superoxide anion production in neutrophils and decreased the expression of pro-inflammatory genes (TNFα, IL8, IL17) in mononuclear leukocytes from RA patients. The effects were concentration-dependent, with LM8 showing the best immunomodulating effect among tested fractions.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
effective_dosage: 60, 120, and 180 µg/mL for neutrophils; 120 µg/mL for mononuclear leukocytes.
